Topic.Title: Was Mccain a terrorist? He was sent to bomb civilians

Message.Msg: (make all the additional points you want to, but I don't see much real difference US bombing of civilians in Nam for our insane reasons or others throwing bombs at us for their insane reasons) Principle IV states: "The fact that a person acted pursuant to order of his Government or of a superior does not relieve him from responsibility under international law, provided a moral choice was in fact possible to him". This principle could be paraphrased as follows: "It is not an acceptable excuse to say 'I was just following my superior's orders'". Previous to the time of the Nuremberg Trials, this excuse was known in common parlance as "Superior Orders". After the prominent, high profile event of the Nuremberg Trials, that excuse is now referred to by many as "Nuremberg Defense". In recent times, a third term, "lawful orders" has become common parlance for some people. All three terms are in use today, and they all have slightly different nuances of meaning, depending on the context in which they are used. Nuremberg principles

Topic.Title: Was Mccain a terrorist? He was sent to bomb civilians

Message.Msg: And BOTH of you guys seem to forget that the laws of armed combat allow a certain degree of collateral damage if the target involved is of strategic or operational value and would normally be considered a valid target (like a power plant, or an aspirin factory that by its nature could be rapidly converted to making anything else requiring simple chemical processes). Civilians are not totally off limits, you just don't go out of your way to kill them. That's the biggest difference between a terrorist and a soldier, aside from a lack of uniforms (though there are so many uniforms now there might as well not be any), the terrorist goes out of his way to avoid hard targets and hit soft ones, while the soldier does it the other way around. Thus while one of our B1B's might roll in on a terrorist encampment and disgorge 12 tons of bombs, those same terrorists would plant half a dozen suicide bombers in a market crowded with holiday worshippers and end up killing more people total. The hard target EXPECTS the airstrike, the soft target expects to be left in peace.
